column2: The renowned warriors known as samurai are trained here. Covered in armor head to toe, they represent ideal lifestyle of a warrior in Japan.

Shinto, also known as "Kami-no-michi" (the Way of the Gods), is the indigenous religion of Japan. Despite many of its adherents initially being opposed to the introduction of Buddhism in Japan, the Shinto religion has incorporated many Buddhist aspects over time. The Shinto religion teaches that certain deeds create a kind of ritual impurity, which one should want to have cleansed for one's own peace of mind and good fortune rather than a negative connotation of such impurity, and also focuses on ritual practices to establish a connection between one self and their ancestors. In the game, Shinto followers get a significant bonus to Intrigue, meaning that court life becomes significantly more dangerous. Though the religion lacks a clear hierarchy, the Tenno is represented as the religious head due to having an important ceremonial position.
This character is a descendant of Amaterasu-Omikami, the Shinto Sun Goddess.

The reformed Ainu faith has a Holy Book containing the Ainu creation myth, information about various kamuy, and written renditions of several important yukar. The church also has a standardized liturgy and a formal church hierarchy, rather than relying on disorganized shamans and fortune-tellers.

Ainu paganism is an animistic religion, believing that everything in nature in Ainu Mosir (the Land of the People) has a kamuy, an immortal spirit or god originating in Kamuy Mosir (the Land of the Gods). Bears are seen as particularly important, and hunters traiditionally seek to capture bear cubs to raise in their villages until the cub has grown up, at which point the bear is ritually sacrificed as part of the Iyomante ceremony to return the kamuy to Kamuy Mosir.
The reformed Muist faith has a standardized Holy Book containing founding legends and appropriate sacrifices to both gods and ancestors, as well as a formal church hierarchy.

Muism, or Sinism, is the pre-historic shamanistic folk religion of Korea, which shares some similarities with other religions originating nearby, such as Taoism and Confucianism. Purity is important to the rituals performed.

By taking the various elements of Taoism, Confucianism, and even Buddhism, the reformed Shenist faith has a standardized Holy Book and liturgy, and a formal church hierarchy led by the High Priest, who can be vassalized by secular rulers.

Shenism, Wuism, or Nuoism, is the folk religion of China with multitudes of doctrines and practices. Due to its sheer size and spread, it has influenced if not founded the other local folk religions of both Far East and South East Asia. Its widespread beliefs has resulted in more organized forms of the religion such as Confucianism and Taoism.
The reformed Ryukyuan faith has a standardized Holy Book and liturgy, and a formal church hierarchy led by the High Priest, who can be vassalized by secular rulers.

The Ryukyuan religion is an indigenous belief system to the people of the Ryukyu Islands having animistic roots. Though similar to the Japanese Shinto religion, Ryukyuans believe in the concept of "onarigami", meaning the spiritual superiority of women in stark contrast to Shinto.
The reformed Thanist faith has a standardized Holy Book and liturgy, and a formal church hierarchy led by the High Priest, who can be vassalized by secular rulers.

Thanism is the folk religion of the Viet people as well as the Cham and Khmer people. Having a lot of similarities with the various Chinese religions, Thanism incorporates various local traditions thus tends to be diverse in ways of practice.

Confucianism was found by the Chinese philosopher Confucius (Kong Fuzi ("Master Kong"), born Kong Qiu) in the 5th century B.C. The religion flourished not only China, but also heavily influenced society in other parts of East Asia such as Korea, Japan, and Vietnam. In the game, Confucians get a bonus to dynasty opinion, meaning that they might not need to watch their own kin as closely.

Neo-Confucianism or Lixue, was an attempt to create a rationalistic and secular form of Confucianism, rejecting superstitious and mystical elements of Buddhist and Toaist influence, though it borrowed terms and concepts from both.
